fields.description: Raised from https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-899, customer could not get Bamboo working on geronimo due to conflict between Bamboo jar and jar's shipped with geronimo
fields.summary: Bamboo should support geronimo app server.

fields.description: One of our plans has not run since the plan which triggered it was deleted. The Config for the plan does not show the deleted plan, however the project view does.
fields.summary: Deleting plans with chilldren should warn the user of that fact

fields.description:
there are many messages in the error log such as:
Build FOO - trunk 2066 : Failed to copy build artifacts using pattern "*/"

All the builds that are listed with that error message are builds that have failed due to compilation errors. If a build fails to compile, you could argue that you woudn't want to copy build artifacts. Perhaps this should be configurable, or at least disabled for build failures.
fields.summary: Artifacts should not be copied if builds fail.

fields.description: In our environment Exchange is used for sending email so we need to be able to connect from Bamboo to an Exchange server to have notification sent out.
fields.summary: using Ms Exchange as a relay host for seding notification

fields.description:
What i think is happening is that on build result summaries with *lots* of broken tests firefox can't manage to display it all.  Maybe this should be paginated or limited to a certain number of tests.

See this page for example: https://jira2.bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/JIRAFUNC-STANDJDK14-1701

I have also attached some screen shots displaying the weird behaviour.
fields.summary: Firefox struggles to display some bamboo pages

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/7.2+Specifying+Bamboo%27s+Working+Directory

The above is not true.  This page should probably just get removed.  There is a manual way (not with in the app gui) to do this but i am not sure if it is worth documenting.
fields.summary: Documentation on Changing Build Working Directory is incorrect.

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to customise the individual perforce commands that get run.  This would be to allow performance optimisation given the users individual environments

For example 
To reduce server load you could use
[p4 changes //path/... | head -1 ] instead of [ p4 changes -m1 //path/... ] 

This could also solve other issues for example, permanently removing the force sync flag.
fields.summary: Ability To customise perforce command lines

fields.description:
The results for Build artifacts has size 4KB (size of a directory entry) and will not take in account the size of artifacts in that directory.
The size calculation should recursively make a sum of sizes of all artifacts.
fields.summary: Size calculation of build artifacts is not right when having directories

fields.description:
The errors clutter up the dashboard.  These should be moved some where else / to their own page and linked to from the dashboard?

Estimate depends on where you want to move it too :)
fields.summary: Remove  Errors From Dashboard

fields.description: Currently Bamboo checks a couple of things before running the start up wizard - whether it has an okay application home, whether it has the right servlet library and whether they have at least Java 1.4.  Now we use all the Java 1.5 stuff,  shouldn't this get updated to check now for 1.5??
fields.summary: Change Bamboo Setup Preconditions to check for a minimum java 1.5 instead of 1.4

fields.description:
The Move Build Plan Wizard tells you disable all build queues and provides you with a link to do so.  This link is broken
{code}There is no Action mapped for namespace /admin and action name triggerPipeline. Check if there is such an action name with such namespace defined in the xwork.xml and also if such an action class exists. Check also the log to see if the action class is successfully loaded. - [unknown location]{code}
and the terminology/wording is incorrect for 2.0.  

From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-894
fields.summary: Warning when moving plans not updated with 2.0 changes (link + text)
Make Bamboo Jira Plugin use Trusted Applications

fields.description: This is mainly because we need the service name to be gmail.com even if the server name is talk.google.com
fields.summary: Jabber connection with talk.google.com doesn't work when using port 443

fields.description:
If a CVSROOT points to symlink Bamboo will see that the path of a detected file doesn't start with the symlink version of the path. This check isn't really required since we're only ever going to get changes from that CVSROOT anyway.

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-839
fields.summary: CVS change detection should be more tolerant of symlinks of CVSROOT

fields.description:
Having multiple levels for organizing plans in, would be a great advantage.
Now you can only configure plans for a specific project, but in our environment we have lots of components for the same project (which is in fact a sub project of a larger project).

As project doesn't have much properties or configurable items, I don't expect it to be much work for introducing multiple levels of them, as they only serve as container for holding plans, but of course I could be wrong :-)
fields.summary: Support for multiple levels in project-plan hierarchy

fields.description:
Assume a Bamboo server on *nix (specifically in our case Solaris 10 x86) and a remote agent on Windows.

You have a Plan with an artifact definition like "**/*" from MyDirectory/output .

All the files come over from the Windows box with backslashes in the file names, which get represented as files with a backslash in them on the Unix side. So for example, if I had an artifact on Windows as:
MyDirectory\output\bin\MyLib.dll
this shows up under Bamboo as a file named
bin\MyLib.dll (note that the backslash is an actual character in the path, and NOT as a directory terminator)

This means that for a hierarchy like **/* you end up with every file in one directory with the full path in and backslash characters.

Ideal behavior here would be to have the artifact copier to automatically detect the path.terminator character and translate between the two platforms.
fields.summary: Artifacts don't respect differing path separation characters on Windows and Unix

fields.description:
If you restart your Bamboo metadata/JMS installation, yoru build agents fail and shut down.

It would be a very useful enhancement to have your build agents be able to wait and retry connections, particularly if you're just momentarily bouncing your installation. Otherwise you have to go and manually relaunch all your agents every time you want/need to cycle your Bamboo server.
fields.summary: Remote build agents should be able to survive server restarts

fields.description: Provide a log4j.properties file to control logging on the remote agent, the current implementation (of agent logging) - picks up the master log4j.properties file from the server and is shared by *all* the remote agents.
fields.summary: Configurable log4j.properties for the remote agent

fields.description:
Assuming you have build plans which require unique access to shared infrastructure at a given point in time (such as shared development databases, for which you can have multiple plans which access the same database, but not at the same time), it would be useful to have an option to state that only one of certain plans can be running at the same time.

The basic use case here is distributed test runs. Assuming that your basic plans are:
- Build (exactly 1 plan)
- Test (10 plans for testing in different environments and with different configurations, but which have to be run serially)
You would want completion of the Build plan to schedule all 10 Test plans, but you want to make sure that no matter how many build agents you have available, only 1 Test plan runs concurrently.
fields.summary: "Don't Build Concurrently With" Plan Option

fields.description:
At the moment it's possible to have multiple plans build concurrently. It's sometimes desirable to be able to build a single plan even when a build is currently in progress.

This does bring in some complexity on the UI front. Which builds would you like to monitor on the Plan screen? Will the logs be spliced? What if the second build finishes before the first build?


From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=25981&tstart=0
fields.summary: Ability to have multiple simultanoues builds for a single plan

fields.description:
The build logs are currently stored uncompressed.  After artifacts these are the largest user of space on the disk.  Teams want to keep these around but in practice they are rarely accessed.  Bamboo should be able to compress these while still keeping them viewable.  This will probably be a net performance win as Bamboo can send these directly to the browser compressed.

h3. From BAM-20267
Artifacts may contain large number of small files. In this case would be useful having the option to zip them automatically and store them zipped (to save space).

Ones the artifacts get downloaded in order to be used in another plan/deployment they should be unzipped automatically also.

Feature already implemented for Amazon S3 artifact handler:
{quote}you can define a maximum number of files per artifact; if this threshold is exceeded the artifact is automatically zipped into a single file, which reduces the number of requests to S3 when uploading and downloading the artifacts and improves the efficiency of the whole process.
{quote}
[https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/artifact-handlers-938641848.html]
fields.summary: Build logs should be compressed

fields.description:
The cache for the SVN externals never expires, and could lead to externals being stale. Externals are cached because they can be very slow to figure out.

We should implement a smarter cache and / or an easy way to update the cache.
fields.summary: Subversion externals are cached until next plan edit / server restart

fields.description:
Not sure if this is a big problem or not, as it is a matter of timing.

Visible Behaviour:

When you kill Bamboo too quickly after importing the permissions don't seem to get persisted, so you can't do anything when you restart.
I have only seen this with HSQL. But can consistently reproduce it.   To reproduce stop the bamboo instance (with idea) directly after the import has complete (I do it as soon as i see the "import complete" message in the browser).  Import is kicked off from admin section.

Looking into the database to see if anything else is going missing, the only thing i can be sure about is the shared capabilities are missing.

Tailing the defaultdb.log file during import shows that the capabilityset, capabilities, queues and permissions are all written to the database after the manual session flush (the one in the session factory) AND after the message goes back to the user telling them to restart. Though they do happen pretty much straight away after this. 

Other thoughts:

* Both the permissions and the capabilities are saved using the respective dao's to save imported data rather than the session in the session factory.
* Perhaps the dao is not flushing to the database straight away. 
* A manual flush of the session in the session factory is performed at the end of the import
* I could not reproduce this on Postgres.
fields.summary: On HSQL some data lost on import if you kill Bamboo too quickly afterwards

fields.description:
With Bamboo 1.2 we used to define a global variable "perforcePort" to use in the "Port:" field for our Plan's repository configurations.  We have two available perforce servers (main and a mirror).  We've had stability issues with the mirror, and occasionally need to switch back to the main server.  Having a single point of configuration (via the global variable) was useful.  

Our port fields look like this: "${bamboo.perforcePort}".

Since upgrading to Bamboo 2.0 the variable no longer appears to be substituted before code changes are detected.

I've attached the relevant log. 

Individually switching all of our build plans back and forth between servers is not fun, and error-prone.
fields.summary: Global Variables not substituted in Perforce Repository Configuration

fields.description:
I just had an instance where I wanted to separate out a bunch of plans from our one project and put them into a new, different, project.  It was very hard to do.  This is because there's no option to just "Create New Project" -- you can only create a project when you create a plan.  But, to create a plan you need to connect it to an SCM and checkout some code and run a build...  That's a lot of work.  When moving plans you also don't have the option to move into a "New Project" (creating it on the fly).

To workaround this, I had to create a new plan in a new project, move the to-be-moved plans to that new project, and delete the temporary plan.
fields.summary: "Move Plan To New Project"

fields.description:
When the build via a remote build agent is finished, the transfer of build result artifacts is initiated.
In our situation, these files can be 500-700 megabytes.

The CPU gets completely taken by the java process (sometimes 99% CPU usage) when transferring these artifacts. I guess there is a lot of overhead in encapsulating the data for transferring through ActiveMQ?

The result of this intensive usage is that the remote bamboo clients are offline (all of them in batches, so this isn't caused by a network problem), probably by a missing heartbeat due to the load.

Can the performance of transferring files to the Bamboo server be increased, or made less CPU intensive?
fields.summary: Tranfering artifacts of large size require too much CPU resources

fields.description: Our svn server sends out emails. We send emails from svn to our homgrown build system as event dispatches, which treats incoming emails as a message queue, filters out relevant events based on svn path in the message body, and start new builds accordingly. We find this approach to be efficient (event is dispatched immediately), less risky (our svn server can avoid potential hangs because because it is not opening tcp sockets via http requests), and low cost with a proven technology (email and smtp).
fields.summary: Trigger buids via E-mail

JRA-568) is ability to find out which build an issue is fixed in. Users should be able to specify the "fixed in" Bamboo build for a JIRA issue.

fields.description:
We are currently evaluating Bamboo with the intent to purchase.  However, we have run into issues getting any of the plug-ins to work.  Specifically the Bamboo SFTP Publisher Plugin and the Coverage Plugin.

The installation instructions for each of the plugins say basically the same thing: Install the jar in <Bamboo install directory>/webapp/WEB-INF/lib and Start or restart the Bamboo server.

We have done so for both, and checking the System Information tab under Administration lists them as Enabled Plugins.  Yet, when we go to the configuration tab for any of the builds we have set up, the additional parts needed to configuration the plugins are not showing up.  (Code Coverage does not show up under the Builder Tab, and SFTP does not show up under the Post Actions tab)

Is this a limitation of the Evaluation license?  Evaluating the SFTP ability at a minimum is required for us before we purchase.
fields.summary: Installed Plug-ins not showing up in Plan Configuration Screens

fields.description:
I'm running a remote build which uses TestNG and Selenium to generate test results using a remote Bamboo agent on WindowsXP. On the remote agent, the build runs as expected and the reports (and directory structure) are created with no issues.

I have an artifact copy pattern which will recursively match the contents of the reports directory, so that I can review all of the reports after the build process (Bamboo parses some of these reports as well). My fileset is as follows:
Label: Reports
Directory: testrun
Pattern: **/*
(on a side note, I also tried **\* as the pattern)

When the artifact processor runs, the contents of the directory are matched as expected on the remote agent, but when the artifacts are copied to/recreated on the Bamboo server, the Windows directory separator is retained, so no directories are created and instead files are written out to the root of the download-data/artifacts/build-nn/Reports directory in the form "directoryname\filename.ext".

For example, here is an abbreviated directory listing on the server:
Smoking\add-1node.html
Smoking\add-1node.properties
Smoking\add-1node.xml
Smoking\classes.html
...
testng-failed.xml
testng-results.xml
testng.css

The expected behavior here is that the directory "Smoking" would be created, and then the appropriate artifacts copied into it.

This also causes problems within the Bamboo UI, as I cannot browse through my report artifacts for a completed build as the expected directory structure does not exist.
fields.summary: Artifact copies from a remote Windows agent to a Linux Bamboo server use incorrect directory separator

fields.description:
Remote agents can take considerable time to start up, especially over a high-latency connection.

There are a number of things we could do to reduce this:
* Cache classes in the agent-side file system.
* Ensure that HTTP keep-alive is used for remote classloading.
* Predictively send required classes.

See [this forum thread|http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=25745&tstart=0] for an example.
fields.summary: Reduce start-up time of Remote Agents

fields.description:
When upgrading from 2.0.x to another 2.0.x here's the process I follow:

1. Make new, empty database.
2. Export XML in previous version.
3. Re-deploy new Bamboo.
4. Point it at new, empty database.
5. Import the previously exported file.

As soon as the import is done, every build we have is put on the queue for an 'initial, clean' build. If I delete builds off the queue they come back on the next round of checks, so ultimately I have to wait out around 170 builds. I've tried restarting Bamboo a second time and the builds always find their way back to the queue.

Bamboo does, however, know (on some level) that it is not an initial, clean build because the previous latest build numbers are still in tact (they don't all reset to 1.)

Of secondary, and probably related, concern is the fact that after the upgrade all our build artifacts seem to be gone. All the build results, logs, etc. are there but the artifacts are physically gone from the bamboo-home\xml-data\builds\...\download-data\artifacts\... directories. Of course, the initial, clean build artifacts are there. Our artifacts have a practical lifespan of exactly one build so no big deal for us but I thought you'd want to know.

I suspect this is a product of importing to a new, clean database instead of converting/upgrading the previous one, but I always like to have a clean, simple rollback procedure in case something goes haywire (by no fault of Bamboo's, of course!)

This has happened for both our upgrades from 2.0 to 2.0.1 and from 2.0.1 to 2.0.2. Also, in helping test a snapshot build of 2.0.3 for fixes to the Perforce integration, it still does the same thing.

Thanks for listening!
fields.summary: After upgrade all builds are queued

Chat transcript:

6:26:23 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: we need a modification to the bamboo API
6:27:37 PM Edwin: ok.
6:27:57 PM Edwin: which one? when?
6:28:03 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: in the build info
6:28:04 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: the commit files
6:28:06 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: that come back
6:28:08 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: have no full path
6:28:14 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: and you can't get (remotely) the SCM details
6:28:18 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: so you get /PL/foo/pom.xml
6:28:22 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: but you don't know which repo!
6:30:17 PM Edwin: but each plan is always tied to one repo?
6:30:29 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: right - but how can I know that remotely?
6:31:19 PM Edwin: buildPlanDefinition.getRepository?
6:32:53 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: hrm - let me look
6:33:08 PM Edwin: hm. which remote API are you calling?
6:33:19 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: getBuildInfo
6:34:25 PM Edwin: build info?
6:34:30 PM Edwin: this is against trunk?
6:36:08 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: let me check the exact method we're calling
6:36:18 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: you get back like <commitfile>/PL/pom.xml</commitfile>
6:39:50 PM Edwin: right.
6:40:02 PM Edwin: think you're calling getBuildResultsDetails
7:49:59 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: uhm, yup - that's the one
7:50:20 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: really I think we should return something like <commitfile>/PL... </commitfile><repository>http://svn.atlassian.com... </repository> ?
7:50:35 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: or even <commitfile repository="">/PL... </commitfile>
7:50:42 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: makes it easier to get hte info you need in one call
7:50:48 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: and if we do the second we don't markedly change the API
fields.summary: Include identity of repository in response to getBuildResultsDetails Remote API method

fields.description: Issues like BAM-560 are, I'm guessing, a relatively complicated problem to solve by mucking with build queue ordering. As it stands now, with arbitrary build queue ordering, multiple dependency paths will eventually resolve correctly, but may generate false build failures when some project builds out of order. Obviously, it would be best if that failure never happens, but an option that might work at my place would be to hold off sending out failure notifications for some X amount of time to see if an alternate dependency path will come around and rebuild the project successfully. This could cut down on a lot of the "false positive" build failures that get sent out where I work, leading a lot of people to start ignoring them.
fields.summary: Add option for notifications to be sent out after X minutes of build plan in a failing state

fields.description:
Ability to use the latest changelist/changeset as the buildnumber for the plan.
This makes the build plan key be much more informative about it's content,
since it's possible to just get the information from VCS based on the key name
as the changeset number.

CruiseControl has the P4ChangelistLabelIncrementer that is used for this purpose, and its much better to use it in perforce projects than the standard label incrementer, which increments each build by +1
{quote}
P4ChangelistLabelIncrementer

"Creates a label from either a given Perforce changelist number, or the most recently submitted changelist. A changelist number can be a good choice for labeling builds from Perforce, because a changelist indicates a particular state of the depot at a moment of time which will never change."
{quote}source: [http://cruisecontrol.sourceforge.net/main/configxml.html#labelincrementer]
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo build number to be determined from Perforce or Subversion changeset/changelist

fields.description:
Consider a scenario where there is a large Subversion repository with its root at the URL:

  http://svn.example.com/repository/

a Bamboo plan is configured to be checked out from the following location in the Subversion repository:

  http://svn.example.com/repository/organisation/department/project/module/

Consider that there is a departmental instance of Fisheye, configured with a repository named "deptrepo", located at:

  http://svn.example.com/repository/organisation/department/

So, the FishEye URL corresponding to the Bamboo plan is:

  http://fisheye.example.com/browse/deptrepo/project/module/

Bamboo's Fisheye integration does not currently support such a configuration, as it will attempt to construct a FishEye URL containing the "organisation/department" components of the plan's Subversion URL, even those these are not visible in the FishEye view of the repository.

*In particular, this problem affects integration of Bamboo with JIRA Studio.*

There may be workarounds that make use of mod_rewrite to perform URL translation.
fields.summary: FishEye integration should support FishEye instances configured to view a subset of a VCS repository

fields.description:
In some fields in the bamboo.cfg.xml the ${bambooHome} property is used.  This gives the impression that it could be used by all of the properties, however each property needs to be converted  as it is retrieved. The conversion has not been set up for some of the properties.  This behaviour should be a) explicitly defined as possible fro specific fields, b) capable of being used for all, or, c) removed altogether.  Do we even use half of these properties?

This issue arises from https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-766:
The "bamboo.config.directory" property does not allow the use of the ${bambooHome} which can cause Upgrade Task 609 to fail. Causing this error:

{code}
2008-05-04 20:11:57,184 INFO [main] [UpgradeManagerImpl] -------------------------------------------------------------------------
2008-05-04 20:11:57,184 INFO [main] [UpgradeManagerImpl] Running upgrade task 609 : Convert builder and jdk to server capabilities
2008-05-04 20:11:57,184 INFO [main] [UpgradeManagerImpl] -------------------------------------------------------------------------
2008-05-04 20:11:57,190 WARN [main] [UpgradeTask609BuilderAndJdkToCapabilities] Upgrade Task 609 not run. The administration.xml configuration file not found
2008-05-04 20:11:57,193 ERROR [main] [UpgradeManagerImpl] java.io.FileNotFoundException: Did not find administration.xml config file.
java.io.FileNotFoundException: Did not find administration.xml config file.
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.UpgradeTask609BuilderAndJdkToCapabilities.doUpgrade(UpgradeTask609BuilderAndJdkToCapabilities.java:68)
{code}
fields.summary: Use of ${bambooHome} in bamboo.cfg.xml

fields.description:
We had a build on BEAC that went AWOL because an agent heartbeat got dropped. The build was:

https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CONFFUNC-RESINHSQL-1058

The errors on Bamboo showed the problem:

Build Confluence Trunk - Resin, HSQL 1058  : Remote agent Remote 2 (Trunk) detected to have gone offline while building.
      (May 2, 2008 1:01:55 AM)

It looks like the build was forgotten by Bamboo and the results never got picked up.

The previous build on this plan also failed for some unknown reason. I couldn't raise a bug about this because I'm not sure of the cause.
fields.summary: Bamboo loses build when agent heartbeat fails

fields.description:
Some builds can only be performed by a single agent (or small number of agents) . If that agent goes down then that build won't get executed until someone notices that the agent is down.

If the agent goes down it would be great to receive notification, in a similar way to the way you get informed about build failures.
fields.summary: Send notification of Agents going offline

fields.description:
Raise from https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-773

Artifacts can be viewed/downloaded by anonymous users even when anonymous access is restricted at a global level. (Seems it doesn't look to the global level when evaluating permissions)

To replicate:
* create an artifact (note the url)
* remove global anonymous access
* logout
* enter the artifact url
fields.summary: Artifacts are not restricted by removing global anonymous access

fields.description:
If using the devenv.com functionality in the nant plugin, there are a couple of build scenarios that would be great if the plugin could handle.

It would be great if the plugin could  be configured to:

 -- run with a list of build options whose build order can be configured 
 -- run a list of failure build options that are executed if failure occurs.


All of these options could be setup and run against a solution in a single build plan.    Relevant Visual Studio build options are for example /build,  /rebuild, /Debug, /Release.  I was thinking one could setup a list of standard and failure actions that the build must iterate through in order to pass.  ex:

standard actions:

/build Debug
/build Release

failure build actions:

/rebuild Debug
/rebuild Release

Currently to support a separate build configuration you must configure a separate plan.  This would eliminate creating two or more plans (one for each configuration) and chaining them together with Parent-Child dependencies with the children being a manual build only.  

The "failure" build option would help clear up a build breakage that can only be cleaned up by performing a /Rebuild, which does happen from time to time and currently requires manual intervention to resolve if a plan only builds a solution with the /build option.
fields.summary: devenv functionality in nant plugin
